quiz.title: Unit 7: Imperfect Competition (Quiz 8)
quiz.subtitle: AP Microeconomics — Monopoly and Imperfect Competition Pricing
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Monopoly, Profit Maximization, MR vs MC vs Price, Imperfect Competition Behavior, Long-Run Comparison, Monopolistic vs Perfect Competition, Game Theory, Lump-Sum Tax, Monopolist Output Region, P > MR Reason, Oligopoly vs Monopolistic Competition, Long-Run Monopoly Profits

questions.question: If a monopoly is producing at the profit maximizing quantity, which of the following must be true?
options: Marginal Revenue > Marginal Cost = Price
Marginal Revenue = Marginal Cost = Price
Marginal Revenue = Marginal Cost < Price
Marginal Revenue < Marginal Cost = Price
Marginal Revenue > Marginal Cost < Price
questions.explanation: A monopoly maximizes profit where MR = MC. Because the demand curve is downward sloping, price (P) is greater than marginal revenue (MR). Therefore, at the profit‑maximizing quantity: MR = MC < P.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about imperfectly competitive firms (monopoly, oligopoly, and monopolistic competition) that profit maximize?
options: They price at marginal cost
They must lower price to sell more units of output
They charge the price determined by the market
They maximize economic surplus
They minimize deadweight loss
questions.explanation: Imperfectly competitive firms face downward‑sloping demand curves, meaning they must lower price to increase quantity sold. They do not price at MC (a), are not price‑takers (c), do not maximize total surplus (d), and create rather than minimize deadweight loss (e).

questions.question: Which of the following is true for both a perfectly competitive firm AND monopolistically competitive firm in the long run?
options: Price equals marginal cost
Price is greater than marginal cost
Price is equal to average revenue
Price is equal to marginal revenue
Marginal revenue is equal to average total cost
questions.explanation: Price equals average revenue for all firms by definition (AR = TR/Q = price). Perfect competition has P = MC and P = MR, but monopolistic competition has P > MC and P > MR. Only (c) holds true for both market structures in the long run.

questions.question: Which of the following is true for a monopolistically competitive firm but NOT true for a perfectly competitive firm?
options: Profit maximizing quantity is where marginal cost equals marginal revenue
Marginal revenue is less than demand
Allocatively efficient quantity is where marginal cost equals price
Productive efficient quantity is where marginal cost equals average total cost
Economic profits will be zero in the long run
questions.explanation: Monopolistically competitive firms face a downward‑sloping demand curve, so MR < P (demand). Perfectly competitive firms face a horizontal demand curve where MR = P (demand). All other options are either true for both or false for monopolistic competition.

questions.question: Game Theory is used to explain:
options: Why firms price discriminate
How monopolies evolve into oligopolies
Strategic behavior of firms in oligopoly
Profit maximization in monopoly
Price leadership of monopolistic competition
questions.explanation: Game theory is the primary tool for analyzing strategic interaction and interdependence among firms in an oligopoly, such as in pricing, output decisions, and reactions to competitors' moves.

questions.question: Assume a profit maximizing monopoly was subject to a lump sum tax. Which of the following will occur?
options: Price and quantity will stay the same
Price will increase and quantity will decrease
Price will increase but quantity will stay the same
The consumer surplus would get smaller
The monopoly would produce the socially optimal quantity
questions.explanation: A lump‑sum tax is a fixed cost that does not affect marginal cost or marginal revenue. Therefore, the profit‑maximizing output and price (determined by demand at that output) remain unchanged.

questions.question: Assume that Prescott Pharmaceuticals, which holds patents on Vaxadrin, Vaxadrine, and Vaxadrone is an unregulated monopolist. Its profit‑maximizing quantity will always be somewhere...
options: where marginal revenue equals price
where price equals marginal cost
where the marginal cost curve intersects the demand curve
in the region of the demand curve where marginal revenue is negative
in the region of the demand curve where marginal revenue is positive
questions.explanation: A monopolist maximizes profit where MR = MC. Since MC is positive, MR must be positive at equilibrium. This occurs in the elastic portion of the demand curve, where MR > 0.

questions.question: Price (Demand) exceeds marginal revenue for the pure monopolist because:
options: the law of diminishing returns doesn’t apply
the demand curve lies below the marginal revenue curve
the monopolist produces a smaller output than would a purely competitive firm
the demand curve is inelastic
to sell more the monopolist must lower its price
questions.explanation: Because a monopolist faces a downward‑sloping demand curve, selling an additional unit requires lowering the price on all units sold, which makes marginal revenue less than price.

questions.question: One difference between oligopolies and monopolistically competitive markets is that
options: There is no deadweight loss in monopolistically competitive markets, but there is in oligopolies
The products sold in monopolistically competitive markets are identical
Oligopolies have fewer barriers to entry
Firms maximize profits in monopolistically competitive markets but not in oligopolies
There are fewer firms in oligopolistic markets than in monopolistically competitive ones
questions.explanation: Oligopolies consist of a few large firms with significant market power and interdependence, while monopolistically competitive markets have many small firms with differentiated products and free entry/exit.

questions.question: Pure monopolists may obtain economic profits in the long run because:
options: they advertise extensively
marginal revenue is constant as sales increase
barriers to entry keep other firms from entering the market
diseconomies of scale keep costs low
the demand for their products are inelastic
questions.explanation: Long‑run economic profits for a pure monopolist are sustained by barriers to entry (e.g., patents, control of resources, legal protections) that prevent new firms from entering and competing away those profits.

scoreMessages.100: Mastery of all Unit 7 topics: monopoly pricing, market structure comparisons, game theory, tax effects, oligopoly vs. monopolistic competition, and barriers to entry.
scoreMessages.90: Excellent — minor review needed on firm number distinctions and barriers to entry.
scoreMessages.80: Strong — focus on differences between market structures and long‑run profit sustainability.
scoreMessages.70: Good — review why monopolies earn long‑run profits and key distinctions among imperfect competition types.
scoreMessages.60: Needs work — key concepts: MR = MC rule, demand elasticity, barriers to entry, and game theory.
scoreMessages.50: Foundational review recommended: profit‑maximizing conditions and characteristics of each market structure.
